context_used: This year's report was published on 5 January 2026. Download Full Report Overview2026 is a tipping point year. It's a time of great geopolitical uncertainty. Not because there's imminent conflict between the two biggest powers, the United States and China—that isn't even a top risk, it's a red herring this year. There's not (yet, at least) a second Cold War, with a rising China remaking the global system to its own liking, the Americans and allies resisting. The most dangerous front in Europe will shift from the trenches in Donetsk to the hybrid war between Russia and NATO. ... The most economically interventionist American administration since the New Deal will pick winners and losers at a scale not seen in modern US history. ... Beijing won’t break out of its deflationary trap this year; instead, it will keep trying to export its way out, flooding global markets with cheap goods at everyone else’s expense. Spheres of influence. Sell America. Eurasia Group’s 2026 Red Herrings. ... These addendums for Brazil, Canada, Europe, and Japan further illustrate how global risks play out in different parts of the world, with specific implications for governments and businesses. Trump is attempting to dismantle checks on his power, capture the machinery of government, and weaponize it against his enemies, making the United States the principal source of global risk in 2026.

gpt_4o.output: The 2026 report highlights significant geopolitical uncertainty, focusing on the hybrid war between Russia and NATO in Europe, rather than a direct US-China conflict. It notes the US government's unprecedented economic intervention and predicts China will continue to deal with deflation by exporting cheap goods. Global risks also emerge from former President Trump's efforts to consolidate power, positioning the United States as a major source of global instability.

gemini_flash.output: The 2026 report highlights geopolitical uncertainty with a shifting European conflict and China's economic strategy. Key risks include the US becoming a major source of global risk due to potential dismantling of governmental checks and balances, and China's attempt to export its way out of deflation. These global risks will have specific implications for governments and businesses worldwide.
